channel.title: Comments on: “Cause he’s down by the pond playing hockey with the kids…”

item.title: By: Open Minded Observer
item.dc:creator: Open Minded Observer
item.description:
Thank you for sharing this story with your readers! "Chirping" is considered part of the game in youth hockey and as you've pointed out, teams are generally lacking in diversity (to put it mildly). So, it's no surprise that racial slurs and mocking of the sort you've described happen on the ice, on the bench and even in the locker room. As you noted, local sanctioning bodies, officials and coaches are often ill equipped to deal with incidents and would prefer to remain safely in their White bubble and ignore issues.
The good news is that's changing... slowly, but there has been progress. Organizations and sanctioning bodies are adopting new policies and Coaches and officials are receiving training on those policies. Everyone can still choose to sweep issues under the rug, but with a little advocating from the parents, everyone at least has procedures to follow and incidents will be recorded.
Organizations like Players Against Hate have been working with the NHL and USA Hockey to try and raise awareness and get policies and training in place. Getting people to even acknowledge there's an issue was an uphill battle and recently USAH emailed every player and their parents a letter which highlighted the issue and outlined policy changes.

item.title: By: Paul Harvey
item.dc:creator: Paul Harvey
item.description:
Nanette,
Thanks for your perspective on this recent incident. The silence of otherwise well intentioned "good" white people only serves to help prop up and maintain the oppressive system of white supremacy, as it has for 400 years now. Instead of thinking of our silence as simply "keeping the peace", we might want to consider the historical and ongoing trauma and violence our silence enables.
We all must push past our comfort zone in our pursuit of a truly liberated and just society.
Thanks also for that amazing and very powerful presentation Saturday on the book White Fragility. You are a radical bridge building warrior woman! But this was seriously courageous, passionate, and heartfelt stuff. Thank you so much. Hopefully you're able to continue advancing this essential and groundbreaking work into the future.

item.title: By: Mara Koven-Gelman
item.dc:creator: Mara Koven-Gelman
item.description:
Hi Nanette, This is excellent!!!! I love how you use White Fragility to examine and call out the racist actions of hockey league and those in the stands. In language of the Holocaust or other genocides, we say that it takes three people to allow a genocide to occur: the perpetrator, the victim and the bystander. You are noting that in the hockey racist event, the team mates and those in the stands were bystanders and equally guilty. Society has to encourage people to not be bystanders (there are a lot more of them, than victims and perpetrators.) Good luck on Saturday.
